snippet: Flexibility on state requirements may lessen opposition, but a national standard where all Americans enjoy the same benefits is still best.
abstract: Editorial asserts that the Obama administration's decision to allow states to define 'essential health benefits' that must be provided to their citizens under the health care reform law may lessen opposition to the law's implementation; argues that federal health officials should find a way to move toward a system in which all Americans enjoy the same benefits with only limited state-by-state adjustment.
lead_paragraph: Flexibility on state requirements may lessen opposition, but a national standard where all Americans enjoy the same benefits is still best.
